repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Telecommunications
            Regulatory Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Caracas Slum-Upgrading
            Project in Venezuela were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: 1) Building up a successful institution is
            time-consuming and challenging and requires close Bank
            supervision, especially during changes of Government
            administration; 2) Closing an institution implies a thorough
            review of all its assets; 3) Internet community centers
            require a specific use; 4) Approval processes within an
            institution must be designed bearing in mind that there is a
            tradeoff between time and exhaustiveness; 5) A good Spectrum
            Monitoring and Administration System (SMAS) requires more
            than just the equipment; 6) Mobile networks are very active
            and expand in a timely manner; 7) Cross-sector projects
            require commitment and coordination from all involved
            parties; and 8) It is better to have an independent
            regulator. However, it must be said that, in the case of
            Dominican Republic, this fact did not became an obstacle
            that hindered the development of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Telecommunications
            Regulatory Reform Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Within the strategic context, to ease
            infrastructure constraints to private sector development and
            increase basic infrastructure coverage, the
            Telecommunications Regulatory Reform Project will strengthen
            the policy, legal, and, regulatory environment in the
            telecommunications sector. It will also improve rural access
            to services through private sector investments. The four
            main components will: 1) create new telecommunications
            regulatory measures, drafting regulations for
            interconnection agreements, licenses, resolution of
            disputes, as well as radio frequency use and management,
            and, different types of existing and new services. Tariffs
            will be reviewed, in addition, design and administration of
            the Fund for the Development of Telecommunications (FDT)
            will be implemented; 2) create an autonomous
            telecommunications regulatory entity, through the
            appointment of executive management and staff, and define
            organizational functions. Procurement of monitoring
            equipment, and, office/computer equipment will be provided,
            together with technical assistance; 3) transfer regulatory
            functions to the Dominican Institute of Telecommunications
            (INDOTEL) upon the closure of the Directorate General of
            Telecommunications (DGT), and, severance compensation will
            be funded; 4) finance and manage the project management unit
            and INDOTEL, to include project audits.
